title: How the â€˜French Murdochâ€™ carried Le Penâ€™s far right to the brink of power
text: How the â€˜French Murdochâ€™ carried Le Penâ€™s far right to the brink of power French tycoon Vincent BollorÃ© has put his sprawling media empire at the service of Franceâ€™s nationalist right, precipitating a rightward shift in French politics. Pulling strings from behind the scenes in the manner of Rupert Murdoch, the billionaire corporate raider has orchestrated an alliance of bitter right-wing rivals in the run-up to Sundayâ€™s legislative elections, bolstering the far-right National Rallyâ€™s chances of victory. When conservative leader Eric Ciotti plotted his startling alliance with Marine Le Penâ€™s National Rally (RN), shattering decades of Gaullist tradition, the head of Les RÃ©publicains (LR) consulted none of his senior party colleagues â€“ not even Nicolas Sarkozy, the last of his political family to serve as French president. Instead, the morning after President Emmanuel Macron called a snap election on June 9, Ciotti paid a visit to BollorÃ©, the billionaire corporate raider who has built a sprawling media empire precisely to engineer such an alliance. The purpose of the visit, revealed by French daily Le Monde, was to â€œorchestrate Ciottiâ€™s rallying behind the RNâ€ â€“ and to prepare for the backlash it was certain to provoke. When Ciotti went public the next day, drawing furious condemnation from party officials, BollorÃ©â€™s media empire was ready to rally to his defence. â€œEric Ciotti has listened to grassroots supporters; it happens, sometimes, to a political leader,â€ said Pascal Praud, one of BollorÃ©â€™s star anchors, on the tycoonâ€™s flagship broadcaster CNews. Praud went on to mock Ciottiâ€™s critics within Les RÃ©publicains, claiming their rejection of an alliance with Le Pen proved that â€œthe poor French right is still the stupidest in the world, out of touch, lacking in courage, with no future, and clearly unable to understand anything, least of all its votersâ€. Meanwhile, on the BollorÃ©-owned radio station Europe 1, the head of conservative newspaper Le Figaro lambasted the â€œunfathomable outpouring of anti-Ciotti sentimentâ€, ridiculing the recent electoral record of â€œthe old baronsâ€ of the right. Either Les RÃ©publicains team up with the National Rally, Alexis BrÃ©zet added, or they are simply doomed to vanish. In the run-up to the snap polls, Europe 1 has been told to make space for another of BollorÃ©â€™s star television anchors, Cyril Hanouna, who has actively sought to sponsor a wider alliance of rightwing parties on his popular talk show â€œTouche pas Ã  mon posteâ€. On June 13, with Ciotti in his studio along with representatives of the National Rally and rival far-right outfit ReconquÃªte, Hanouna pulled out his phone to call the RNâ€™s new poster boy Jordan Bardella, handing the handset over to his ReconquÃªte guest â€“ Sarah Knafo â€“ and urging her to plead with Bardella for an alliance. â€˜A personal victory for BollorÃ©â€™ A newly elected European lawmaker, Knafo is the partner of ReconquÃªte founder Eric Zemmour, the former CNews pundit whose presidential run in 2022 enjoyed wide support among BollorÃ©â€™s media. While Zemmourâ€™s ElysÃ©e Palace bid eventually foundered, his unrivalled media exposure ensured the far rightâ€™s preferred topics â€“ immigration, crime and the perceived threat from Islam â€“ dominated the political conversation. It also furthered blurred the line between mainstream conservatives and the far right, providing fertile terrain for the â€œunion des droitesâ€ (alliance of right-wing factions) that has long been BollorÃ©â€™s pet project. â€œUniting the French right and carrying it to power has always been BollorÃ©â€™s principal aim,â€ says Alexis LÃ©vrier, a historian of the media who teaches at the UniversitÃ© de Reims Champagne Ardennes. â€œThat means breaking down the barriers that have long kept the mainstream right and the far right apart â€“ and finding dependable lieutenants, like Eric Ciotti, to bridge the divide,â€ he adds. While Ciottiâ€™s alliance with Le Pen is resisted by virtually all heavyweights in his LR party, voter surveys suggest the move may still pay off. Pollsters say Le Penâ€™s party is poised to win the largest share of votes in the legislative elections scheduled for June 30 and the following Sunday, possibly even clinching an absolute majority of seats in Franceâ€™s lower house of parliament, which wields greater powers than the Senate. The latter outcome would lead to Franceâ€™s first far-right government since the Nazi-allied Vichy Regime â€“ capping an extraordinary turnaround for an extremist party that was co-founded by Le Penâ€™s father Jean-Marie, a Vichy supporter and convicted anti-Semite. â€œBollorÃ© is no personal fan of the Le Pen family brand, but he has recently warmed to the party,â€ says LÃ©vrier. â€œIn Bardella, whom Le Pen has named as her choice for PM, the National Rally has found a candidate that BollorÃ© can support.â€ He adds: â€œIn every respect, the far rightâ€™s likely victory in the upcoming vote would be a personal victory for BollorÃ©, a vindication of what his media empire was designed to achieve.â€ The French Murdoch A deeply conservative Catholic from Brittany, in western France, BollorÃ© has emerged as Franceâ€™s most successful corporate raider, cobbling together a transport, media and advertising empire that stretches across Europe and Africa. Over the past decade, he has gradually expanded his media assets in France to include television channels, a radio station, prominent magazines, Franceâ€™s leading publisher, its biggest travel retail chain and, most recently, its best-known Sunday paper. Far from painless, the takeovers have followed a well-honed strategy, says Alexandra Colineau of the media advocacy group Un Bout des MÃ©dias. â€œThe strategy is to buy established titles and empty their newsrooms, moving in like a hermit crab in an empty shell,â€ she explains. â€œThe shellâ€™s previously acquired credibility is then exploited to advance a radically different agenda.â€ After acquiring news channel iTÃ©lÃ©, part of the Canal+ group, the Breton tycoon provoked a record strike of 31 days in 2016, got rid of most of the staff and turned it into a conservative platform that critics have dubbed â€œFrance's Fox Newsâ€. CNews is now Franceâ€™s most popular news channel â€“ though its many critics say â€œopinion channelâ€ is a more accurate description. The takeover of the Journal du dimanche (JDD) led to an even longer staff walkout last year, triggered by BollorÃ©â€™s appointment of a controversial editor-in-chief whose previous tenure at arch-conservative magazine Valeurs Actuelle included a conviction for racist hate speech over cartoons depicting a Black MP as a slave in chains. Read moreFranceâ€™s Murdoch? Right-wing media swoop threatens â€˜pillar of French democracyâ€™ The billionaireâ€™s aggressive expansion into media has prompted comparisons with media mogul Rupert Murdoch, whose myriad news outlets in Australia, Britain and the United States have fundamentally altered the media and political landscapes of those countries. In both cases, LÃ©vrier pointed to a clear intent to push the debate in a socially conservative direction, pulling strings from behind the scenes while shunning the limelight. â€œMurdoch is clearly BollorÃ©â€™s model,â€ he says. â€œThey both have vast and diversified media conglomerates. And they both aim to win elections without ever running for office.â€ During the JDD standoff last year, historian David Colon, who has written a book about Murdochâ€™s media empire, pointed to parallels between the tycoonsâ€™ respective holdings, highlighting the impact of synergies between television, radio and print. â€œWhen it comes to media concentration, the key factor is not the number of titles you own or the size of their readership, but rather the diversity of the mediums,â€ he explained. â€œItâ€™s this cross-ownership that allows you to set the agenda and rapidly influence public debate.â€ In BollorÃ©â€™s case, the scale of his assets and their ideological slant have created an unprecedented situation for France, adds LÃ©vrier. â€œNever before has so much influence been concentrated in the hands of one man,â€ he says. â€œAnd never before has such influence been used to promote such an extreme agenda.â€ The French Fox News Since 2022, BollorÃ© has twice appeared before parliamentary committees investigating the unprecedented concentration in Franceâ€™s media landscape. On both occasions he struck a faux-naÃ¯f tone as he belittled his assets and denied any political motive. â€œI have no power to appoint people to these channels,â€ he told a Senate panel when quizzed about his role in the many resignations and high-profile firings that rattled the Canal+ media group following his takeover in 2015. He added: â€œSome journalists have left, others have returned. Itâ€™s like the ocean tide, back home in Brittany.â€ Colineau blames a lax legal framework, the bulk of which dates back to 1986, for allowing the likes of BollorÃ© to concentrate media resources and dictate their will. Her association has come up with a series of proposals designed to ensure journalists have their say on the appointment of editors, but she bemoans a lack of political support. Media watchdogs also lament a failure to crack down on BollorÃ©â€™s media outlets â€“ CNews in particular â€“ over their disregard for public broadcasting rules. The â€œFrench Fox Newsâ€ has positioned itself as a straight-talking alternative to mainstream media stifled by political correctness, claiming to serve the French public what it really wants. Critics, however, say the channel has repeatedly violated the terms of a licensing agreement that applies to Franceâ€™s free-to-air news networks, requiring them to provide balanced coverage. â€œCNews provides very little actual news and hardly any investigation, which is more expensive to produce,â€ says Colineau. â€œIt is primarily an opinion channel with a heavy right-wing bias.â€ Read moreHow Franceâ€™s far right changed the debate on immigration Between them, CNews and its sister channel C8, which hosts Hanounaâ€™s talk show, have received a staggering 44 admonishments from Franceâ€™s media regulator Arcom. To date, they are the only French channels to have been fined by Arcom â€“ including for inciting racial hatred after Zemmour branded child migrants â€œthieves, murderers and rapistsâ€. Earlier this year, the Conseil dâ€™ Ã‰tat, Franceâ€™s highest civil administration, gave Arcom a six-month deadline to come up with more coercive measures to ensure the likes of CNews respect the rules. â€œThere are signs that politicians and the authorities are finally waking up to the threat posed by BollorÃ©â€™s media,â€ says LÃ©vrier, noting that CNewsâ€™ broadcasting licence is up for renewal later this year. â€œI think BollorÃ© is aware that a number of safeguards could be reinforced in the coming months,â€ he adds. â€œIn the meantime, his outlets have doubled down on their right-wing rhetoric. Theyâ€™re no longer even trying to pretend their coverage is balanced.â€ In a frantic, three-week election campaign, BollorÃ©â€™s pundits have stepped up their attacks against the left-wing New Popular Front, which has emerged as the far rightâ€™s main opponent in the upcoming polls. Some have labelled the left the â€œanti-Franceâ€ and the â€œparty of foreignersâ€, echoing the rhetoric used by the anti-Semitic nationalist right that collaborated with the Nazis during World War II. Two pundits known for their pro-Kremlin views have gone a step further, running for parliament under a joint RN-LR banner. â€œEven by the standards of BollorÃ©â€™s channels, the radicalism is unprecedented,â€ says LÃ©vrier, describing the upheaval that has swept French politics in recent weeks as â€œhistory acceleratedâ€. â€œThe BollorÃ© camp is engaged in a race, a sprint against democratic checks on the media,â€ says LÃ©vrier. â€œIf it wins that race, we can forget about those safeguards.â€

title: In Notre Dame football recruiting, coach Marcus Freeman says, 'I love multisport guys'
text:
In Notre Dame football recruiting, coach Marcus Freeman says, 'I love multisport guys'
SOUTH BENDâ€” Backgrounds in sports other than football clearly impress the [Notre Dame ](https://www.ndinsider.com/story/sports/college/football/2024/12/04/early-signing-day-updates-for-notre-dame-football-recruiting-marcus-freeman-will-black-jadon-blair/76758627007/)recruiting apparatus.
In addition to established two-sport college athletes Drayk Bowen (linebacker/baseball), Jordan Faison (wide receiver/lacrosse), Tyler Buchner (wide receiver/lacrosse) and Matt Jeffery (wide receiver/lacrosse), Notre Dameâ€™s 2025 [signing class ](https://www.ndinsider.com/story/sports/college/football/2024/12/01/when-do-final-cfp-rankings-come-out-heres-what-notre-dame-football-fans-must-know-marcus-freeman/76689743007/)includes a slew of newcomers that can shine in other sports.
Brandon Logan, the safety/outfielder from Fort Wayneâ€™s Snider High School, was a Vanderbilt baseball commit until Notre Dame came calling.
James Flanigan, the tight end from Green Bay, Wisc., won state titles in hockey and track and field.
Offensive tackle Will Black, the highest-rated recruit in Notre Dameâ€™s 12th-ranked signing class, grew up in London, Ontario playing hockey, basketball and lacrosse before he outgrew those pursuits. Black now stands 6-foot-7 and 292 pounds.
And cornerbacks Cree Thomas (decathlon) and Mark Zackery IV (basketball) have distinguished themselves in non-football ways.
â€œWe have some multisport athletes here at Notre Dame,â€ Irish coach Marcus Freeman said. â€œWe love that. I encourage that. I think itâ€™s something that we put tremendous value in.â€
Last Decemberâ€™s hiring of director of football performance Loren Landow, who has worked with Olympic-class athletes from a variety of sports, has only increased the potential benefits of football-plus athletic backgrounds.
Those benefits cover everything from the physiological to the psychological, from avoiding injury to playing through various thresholds of pain. Freeman, whose eldest son, Vinny, wrestles and plays football at Penn High School; knows that better than most big-time football coaches.
First-hand knowledge of multisport value
At 10, Freeman won an age-group national championship in taekwondo before turning his attention to wrestling and football. At Wayne High School in Huber Heights, Ohio, Freeman competed in track and field in the spring.
â€œI think there are movements that playing in different sports can really help you with in football,â€ Freeman said. â€œYes, thereâ€™s the basic athleticism, movement traits that different sports give you. But the thing I keep coming back to is that competitive spirit.
â€œItâ€™s hard to compete sometimes just going to a (football) trainer, and somebody might say, â€˜Youâ€™re wrong because we compete in our training session.â€™ But I want to see you go head-to-head in track. I want to see you go head-to-head in baseball. Brandon Logan, I want to see you play baseball, and maybe not just look to specialize in one sport.â€
Newly signed offensive tackles Matty Augustine (hockey) and Owen Strebig (baseball) competed in other spots as did defensive lineman Dominik Hulak (hockey). Receivers Elijah Burress and Antavious â€œScrapâ€ Richardson honed their running form as track sprinters; Richardson, in fact, won Georgia state titles in the 100 and 200 meters.
â€œI can go down the list about multisport athletes,â€ Freeman said. â€œI love multisport guys. It keeps you busy, keeps you in shape.â€
And Zackery, like 2024 signee and fellow defensive back Tae Johnson (Fort Wayne North Side) before him, might be as skilled on the basketball court as he is on the football field.
â€œ(Zackery) is one of the few football players who can truly play basketball,â€ Freeman said of the Ben Davis High School star from Indianapolis. â€œMost of our guys that play basketball are football players (who are) just on the basketball court. Heâ€™s a basketball player when heâ€™s on the basketball court. He is a unique talent.â€
On Freemanâ€™s watch, Notre Dame football seems to be collecting those.
Mike Berardino covers Notre Dame football for the South Bend Tribune and NDInsider.com. Follow him on social media @MikeBerardino.

author: Anthony Robledo
title: Viral photo of forlorn Spiral Hot Dogs owner leads to booming business
text: Customer's photo of forlorn owner in empty restaurant leads business to boom at OK diner Nick Chappell had never been to Spirals Hot Dogs & More before he took a photo of Scott Hosek in his empty restaurant. But after business boomed, Chappell's part of the Spirals family, Hosek says. [Anthony Robledo](https://www.usatoday.com/staff/7612431001/anthony-robledo/) An Oklahoma hot dog joint owner visibly wanted customers one day and he soon got more than he bargained for. During a slow shift on Dec. 20, a customer took a photo of Scott Hosek standing by his restaurant entrance waiting for diners and shared it on social media. Hosek would soon have no time to stand around as " [Spirals: Hot Dogs & More](https://spiralshotdogs.com/)," in Norman, Oklahoma, saw booming business once the post went viral. "We immediately started doing double digits in sales," Hosek told USA TODAY on Thursday. "It happened really fast to me." The day the photo was taken, Hosek found himself staring out the window upset his family business of four years wasn't booming as well as others ahead of Christmas. Hosek said he had no idea why Spirals saw a sudden wave of new customers after Dec. 20 until the person responsible for posting the photo, Nick Chappell, later apologized and offered to take the post down. Hosek wouldn't hear of it. "You just wouldn't expect it. Social media is amazing. It's amazing that people get involved with it," he said. "But more importantly, it's the stuff that you just don't think would work. That's what works." 'I will always love you': [See Dolly Parton grant Utah man's dying wish to meet her](/story/life/humankind/2023/12/26/dolly-parton-meets-longtime-fan/72033945007/) Customer knew he had to capture 'wholesome moment' Chappell visited the Norman area for his job as an Oklahoma Army National Guard. As part of their weekly hot dog Wednesday routine, Chappell and a his co-worker found Spirals on Google Maps and took a chance. Noticing Hosek gazing, Chappell decided to capture the "wholesome moment" on Snapchat captioning "He has been standing here waiting on customers to come in." "A good buddy of mine named Chad said, 'Hey, man, you can either post this on Facebook or I'm going to post this on Facebook. Some way or another we're going to get this guy some customers,'" Chappell said. In a Facebook post, Chappell gave an excellent recommendation of the restaurant, complimenting their food and "off the charts" service. He shared a photo of his dish, the menu and of Hosek waiting for diners. Chappell was blown away by the success of the post, which has since had over 2,000 shares, and even more surprised to see over 70 guests at the diner during his next visit. "I'm not a huge social media guy I typically don't share," Chappell said. "I don't even know really the words to describe it as but it made me even that much happier that I did make a post." Owner adds new 'Thunderbird' item in customer's honor Hosek is showing his gratitude by adding a new item in Chappell's honor. Having named hot dogs and bowls after family members, he was more than happy to do so. The "Thunderbird" is a hot link with bacon, cream cheese and jalapeÃ±os, Hosek said. The meal gets its name from the Thunderbird Unit Patch for the 45th Infantry, which Chappell is a part of. The two reconnected at the restaurant on Thursday, where they both got emotional talking about the post's impact. Chappell received a certificate of appreciation during the unveiling of the "Thunderbird" and was told he is now forever part of the Spirals family. "To know that it was a humble guy that just saw our need and did what he could. He doesnâ€™t have a real following on social media, he hardly ever shares anything and to know that one post had so much power. It was super cool," Hosek added.
